Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2008 05:07PM aliciamaris wrote: It sounds like you would be a great candidate for oncotype testing, which will give you a percentage chance of recurrence - this can help make decisions about chemo.  Have you talked to your onc about this?  My basic philosophy is the 'no regrets' approach - will I feel like I didn't do enough if I have a recurrence or develop metastatic disease?  I chose to throw everything possible at the beast (8 cycles of chemo and 35 rads, tamoxifen and lots of supplements), but that's not everyone's choice.  I wasn't eligible for testing because I had 2 positive nodes, but I think it might be helpful in your situation.  best to you Alicia

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2008 12:36PM aliciamaris wrote: I stopped using any product that contains parabens when I was diagnosed.  There are a number of good skin care lines that do not include these preservatives - EarthScience makes some good stuff.  The data is not strong yet, but why take chances?  I also don't want my stepdaughter using things with parabens - her mom and her grandmother had premenopausal bc - why take risks?
Posts.Title: er + link to Parabens ? riverinerabbit riverinerabbit
Pick up a glass of virtual champagne with me katz03 Naomi

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2007 09:54AM aliciamaris wrote: Ginger - my onc told me recently that breast cancer, as a general rule, does not hurt unless it invades other organs - pain in the breast is rarely cancer (I'm not saying NEVER, but rarely).  Chemo does really weird things to your body - I had a lot of pain on Taxol - mostly muscle pain for me, but...If it's still around, get it checked out - you don't need the added stress. hugs Alicia
Posts.Title: Please....not again gshoemate HollyHopes

Posts.Content: May 1, 2008 02:44PM aliciamaris wrote: Oh, Sally - I'm so sorry about your kitty.  I empathize with the 'silent dread' - we have all lost our innocence - a rash is never just a rash, a swollen lymph node is never just the body's response to infection, a headache is never just a headache.  Like you, I don't say anything to others when these fears arise and I feel completely isolated in my fear and pain, except for posting here.  As bc survivors, we are retraumatized at every follow-up doctor's appointment and everytime something unexplainable happens with our bodies.  Then we are further traumatized by being told to wait, and then the ultimate horror of having scans and waiting for results.  It's so hard to find ways to care for ourselves around all of this.  I hold you and kitty in my heart and visualize healing. hugs Alicia
Posts.Title: Silent Dread SLH snowyday

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2008 08:07PM aliciamaris wrote: Hi, ladies I'm having a moment of panic - I have a large red area in the center of my chest (looks like a sunburn but I haven't been out in the sun) and is slightly itchy.  It's not raised and there are no bumps or lumps.  I noticed it after showering today.  I'm freaking out a little and wondering if this sounds familiar to anyone with skin mets. thanks Alicia

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2008 03:27PM aliciamaris wrote: Hi, Carol - I'm nearly 3 years out from tx but had the same protocol (4 AC/4 Taxol over 4 months, with Neupogen shots to keep my cell count up).  My hair started falling out around day 14 after my first chemo - I cut it all off on day 12 and then shaved it around day 16 when it started driving me crazy.  I also live in San Francisco.  Do you have a support group in SF?  Feel free to PM me if you would like. Alicia
